title: A Case for Real Ear Measures
chief_complaint: I notice some benefit with my hearing aids, but I believe I am not hearing as well as I should, particularly in noisy listening situations.

problem_summary.onset: Hearing loss since middle school; recent exacerbation in right ear 2 months ago following URI.
problem_summary.course: Chronic/progressive with recent fluctuation due to middle ear fluid (resolved in right ear after Otovent use).
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: History of ear infections/PE tubes, recent fullness/fluid, difficulty in background noise.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Disappointed with speech understanding in noisy environments despite wearing hearing aids.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Wants to know if ability to understand speech in background noise can be improved.

history.present_illness: Patient initially saw otologist 2 months ago for decreased hearing in RE after URI. Diagnosed with fluid/retracted TM. Prescribed Otovent (auto-inflation). Patient reports immediate improvement in RE after using Otovent.
history.otologic_history: Extensive history of childhood ear infections, multiple myringotomies and PE tubes. Right ear was better ear until recent URI.
history.noise_exposure_history: Significant history: construction work for approximately 40 years.
history.prior_management: Wears bilateral RIC hearing aids (open domes) purchased 3-4 years ago from a large retail chain. Believes he received a 'deal' but travels 4 hours for service.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Normal 250-1000 Hz, precipitous drop to moderate/mod-severe SNHL 1500-8000 Hz. Left ear: Normal 250 Hz, slight mixed loss 500-1000 Hz, precipitous drop to moderate/mod-severe SNHL 1500-8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs consistent with PTA. Word recognition scores excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear normal (Type A). Left ear negative pressure (Type C), indicating possible Eustachian tube dysfunction.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: RE Ipsi normal 500-2k, absent 4k. LE Ipsi elevated/absent. Contralateral reflexes largely absent or elevated, consistent with hearing loss and middle ear status.

tests.name: Real Ear Measures (REM)
tests.key_findings: Minimal insertion gain bilaterally compared to NAL-NL1 targets. Significant under-amplification in high frequencies (1000-6000 Hz). Large Real Ear Unaided Gain (REUG) noted due to large ear canals.

numeric_results.REIG_vs_Target: Measured gain significantly below NAL-NL1 target curve from 1kHz to 4kHz+.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral, precipitous high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, with a slight mixed component in the low-mid frequencies of the left ear and negative middle ear pressure. Word recognition is excellent. Evaluation of the patient's current RIC hearing aids via Real Ear Measures reveals significant under-amplification compared to NAL-NL1 targets, particularly in the high frequencies required for speech understanding in noise.
counseling_points: Your hearing aids are functioning mechanically, but they are not programmed to give you the volume you need in the high pitches.
The 'First-Fit' settings from the manufacturer are providing far less amplification than is prescribed for your hearing loss.
This lack of high-pitch volume is the primary reason you are struggling to understand speech in background noise.
We recommend reprogramming your current hearing aids using Real Ear Measures to match your prescription targets.
Because you purchased the aids elsewhere, there may be a fee for us to reprogram them, or you can return to the original retailer with our findings.
notes_for_actor: You are price-conscious; you drove 4 hours to buy these hearing aids to save money.
You are frustrated that despite the 'deal,' you aren't hearing well in noise.
You are diligent about your health (used the Otovent as instructed) and observant (noticed the improvement).
You have a long history of ear issues (infections, tubes) and are comfortable with medical ear procedures.
